reviewText:
This really is a fantastic social oriented game and it does require a microphone to play it properly.

Players basically find themselves paired up and placed in a rather sizeable mansion consisting of different floors, outer grounds and various hidden passages.

The game is basically a treasure hunt assisted by the various clues that are provided to the player. The first team to find all their loot wins the game.

....Yet there is more.

One player is a devil in disguise and his goal is to murder all the other players whilst trying to hide his identity lest the other players gang up and capture him. The devil, when transformed, is very fast and powerful and especially dangerous to players caught alone, yet it vulnerable to players in groups.

Players have to choose whether to focus on the clues and treasure hunt which leaves them more vulnerable to the devil or stay with others which will dilute their loot search time. Teams can also be much more effective in gathering the loot if they split up but that also leaves them much more vulnerable.

Players also have to consider whether they wish to share the Devil's identity should they find it out. They could even decieved other players and pretend it is someone else in order to sabotage another teams treasure hunt or break the trust between team mates.

The mansion itself is very interactive with peep holes, hiding places, traps and secret doors. Good players will learn the mansion and utlilise it effectively.

Another fantastic aspect to the game is the music. When a player transforms into the Devil a forboding tune acompanies the Devil where he/she wil go and this really sets the atmosphere in the mansion and puts the other players on edge, ya better hide. The other compositions in the game are also very fitting and a few are quite catchy.

I highly recommend this game for people who find the above description compelling. The game certainly is niche and won't please everyone. it is not a shooter and it is not first person. It is what it is and the developers have produced a very polished and playable product that I think is well worth looking into and supporting if it is your kind of thing.

Thumbs up. :)

reviewText:
Devil's Bluff. An 11v1 scavenger hunt where there are 11 survivors and a single devil.

The object of the game is to either win the scavenger hunt, or capture the Devil if you are the survivors. Alternatively if you're Devil, you could murder everybody, or give up your career of soul-snatching and win the hunt yourself.

I have clocked in many more hours than what I have on steam and I love the game, it's great fun. Especially when you have a large group in a game it can get tense when you and another team are neck and neck in the scavenger hunt.

Also, keep in mind that the game is online-only

+ Fun gameplay
+ Team-Based gameplay
+ Good Music
+ Cats. Lots and lots of cats.

There are a couple of gripes I have but they are nothing major. For example, there is an element of luck when it comes to high-level play against good players, such as the run mechanic can sometimes trip you over a lot and bring you to a dead-stop. And The randomly generated clues can give you or others a big advantage early, or late in the game.

It's a great and unique game, and hopefully you check it out.

Devil's Bluff is Great in concept, Messy in execution.

In a full game it's a race between 6 teams of 2 to find 14 items in a scavnger hunt in an huge mansion.  You get a clue on the whereabouts of the item because the item can still spawn in the next room over... don't think you want to be looking for something for the kitchen in the bathroom but it happens.  Normally it's the first team to find all 14 items wins but there is a DEVIL AMONG YOU who's goal it is to kill everyone before that and not get captured in the process.  Basically they transform into devil form, wack you twice and if no one revives you in 90 seconds, You're dead.   The only defense you have is to try and capture them, or smack them and run and hide.

Now here's the part of the game that makes it feel like early access,  this is probably the third time they fixed how hard it is to capture the devil ((impossible at time of writting)) and even if it was balanced it's a race to who can mash their space bar the most ((or set up a marco x.x)) and the only real way to win is to have a slow devil... I rather it be more logically like hey you have to slap him x times then capture...

As far as playing a human goes, there is no way to heal up if you take damage from the devil or traps, like easy to fall in or get slapped in, holes in the floor, and if you die and get revived you only get one devil hit or 2 traps worth of health back.  Now for Scavanger Hunt part, It's the same level with the same layout every time.  Throw in the fact that there are rooms you have to know how to get to... like jumping in a tv or another hidden passage, new players don't have a chance till they learn the map, and the team that knows the most about the clues, will always be the team that wins it.  There is not hint system or anything like that either so if you can't figure out the clue, might as well give up...

That said there is still fun to be had, and the devs are promising patches, one of which later they said will randomize the layout to make it a more fair game but things could always happen.  Right now if you have a couple friends to play this with, it's a fun time, but if you're just buying for yourself, this might not be a good pickup till later.

reviewText:
Devil's bluff is a scavenger hunt game with up to six teams of two.  One player is randomly selected to be the Devil which gives them some extra abilities, namely killing other players, and an alternative win condition.  There is a bit of a learning curve to the game with the mansion layout/passageways and scavenger hunt riddles but it feels extremely rewarding to master these things.

The random nature of the scavenger clues makes the game highly replayable.  I was one of the earliest beta testers and the game hasn't gotten old for me.  Figuring out the safest v fastest to the next clue keeps it very engaging.

The mansion itself is gorgeous and extremely favorful; filled with secret passageways, traps, and hiding spots.  There is ingame chat that is proximity based so it can be important to be quiet when trying to hide.  Nothing raises the tension more than hearing the wolf howl that signals the death of another player.  I forsee this as the next big party game for LP collabs and streams.

Devils Bluff is one of the funnest Cartoon styled Hide and Seek games with a twist that I've ever played. This unlike other games in the Hide and Seek genre gives the hiders something else to do other than just hiding or killing the chaser. ♦ Amazing Death Spectator Mode (Lets you easily view another living player including the Devil)
♦ Nice Help Menu (This is very detailed and a nice way to teach the game without having a full on Tutorial)

GameplayI can't say much on the nature of the game, since I don't have a lot of hours on it yet, but Devil's Bluff seems to be  a rather charming version of Town of Salem. You're tasked with the duty to find treasure and scavenger clues while keeping in mind that, within the mansion walls there are 11 other folks, one of whom is the Devil. The randomly assigned Devil is out to, you guessed it, kill you and it is the scavenger hunters duty to either win the hunt or be the hunted. Spooky...

The mansion is quite large, so there is definitely a ton of map to explore. Even in the little amount of time that I've played, I know for sure that there is more to the map than meets the eye. You're able to run away from other players, hide in various barrels and crates, and traverse through secret passageways and set off remote traps. This keeps up the tension between players, while also offering a nice way to relax and mess around with friends.

GraphicsThe graphcis are, simply put, adorable. You can't really go wrong with these small cartoony characters dressed up in Halloween costumes. They are also quite refreshing: not everyone wants smooth graphics at the sacrifice of amazing gameplay. Devil's Bluff offers both decent graphics with decent gameplay. Win-win situation.

reviewText:
REALLY fun game to play, especially if you can get into a game of 8+. Don't let the 11v1 stuff fool you! If you or your partner are the devil, you BOTH can win really easily. The devil goes out and attacks while the other teammember does the hunt until it's just those two. Then you can finish the hunt and win. Up to you though, devil can just go solo and win it himself/herself.

Big tip: It's damn near impossible to capture the devil solo, so you definitely need a group around to help. Problem is, only the person that starts the capture gets credit for it. All involved should get some sort of credit for taking down the devil.

The scavenger hunt is pretty easy to handle, it'll tell you roughly where you could find the item in the first part of the clue and what the item is in the second part, the second part not really being necessary since you're looking for something different from the usual surroundings.

SLAPS! Slaps are really useful in the game vs players. You can get a few off while running out of the starting area, letting them continue the slapfest while you're on your way to the first clue. Also, you can slap players in a direction and, if set up right, into traps.

When the devil starts killing, keep an eye out for what characters you AREN'T passing. You can use that as deduction as to who the devil is and avoid them.

If more people can start playing it, definitely worth buying, you can get a lot of laughs from playing and get to communicate with the other players with voice chat.

reviewText:
REALLY fun game to play, especially if you can get into a game of 8+. Don't let the 11v1 stuff fool you! If you or your partner are the devil, you BOTH can win really easily. The devil goes out and attacks while the other teammember does the hunt until it's just those two. Then you can finish the hunt and win. Up to you though, devil can just go solo and win it himself/herself.

Big tip: It's damn near impossible to capture the devil solo, so you definitely need a group around to help. Problem is, only the person that starts the capture gets credit for it. All involved should get some sort of credit for taking down the devil.

The scavenger hunt is pretty easy to handle, it'll tell you roughly where you could find the item in the first part of the clue and what the item is in the second part, the second part not really being necessary since you're looking for something different from the usual surroundings.

SLAPS! Slaps are really useful in the game vs players. You can get a few off while running out of the starting area, letting them continue the slapfest while you're on your way to the first clue. Also, you can slap players in a direction and, if set up right, into traps.

When the devil starts killing, keep an eye out for what characters you AREN'T passing. You can use that as deduction as to who the devil is and avoid them.

If more people can start playing it, definitely worth buying, you can get a lot of laughs from playing and get to communicate with the other players with voice chat.

Edit: To the creators: pressing k to use sometimes has an annoying delay, like when I'm trying to escape from the devil and running up and down stairs to slow him/her down. When I'm able to go up/down stairs or through doorways, I need to when I press the button, not mash it until I go through.
